Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: They notice swimmers occasionally entering the shallow area without supervision.
Story: I stood at the edge of the community pool, my whistle hanging around my neck, eyes scanning the water. Today was the day of my family’s annual blessing ceremony, a tradition my father insisted I help lead. He’d called me that morning, his voice full of pride and expectation, reminding me how important it was to honor our heritage. I promised I’d be there, but as the ceremony time approached, the pool grew crowded. Kids darted in and out of the shallow end, some without parents nearby. My supervisor had drilled into me that safety came first—no exceptions. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down on me: my family counting on me to uphold our traditions, my duty as a lifeguard demanding my full attention. My heart pounded as I watched a group of unsupervised children giggling near the water’s edge, while my phone buzzed with messages from home, asking when I’d arrive. I stood frozen, torn between the pull of my family’s expectations and the responsibility to keep everyone safe.
